properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls into Saturday. Snowfall rates under the most intense bands may exceed 5 centimetres per hour at times. Snowfall amounts in excess of 40 cm are possible by Saturday morning. Strong west winds gusting to 60 km/h will combine with the snow to generate near zero visibility at times. Travel will be very poor and may be nearly impossible at times. Motorists are strongly advised to change their travel plans accordingly. ### Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T01:19:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-28T09:20:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0949052433.2020
Area: Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Listowel - Milverton - Northern Perth County, Mount Forest - Arthur - Northern Wellington County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County, Caledon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls into Saturday. A intense snow squall originating from Lake Huron is reaching inland as far as southern Durham region. Snowfall rates under this band may reach or exceed 5 centimetres per hour at times. This snowsquall is crossing highway 400 near highway 89. Motorists should be prepared for poor winter driving conditions including slippery and snow covered roads along with very low visibility in heavy snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T02:50:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-28T10:51:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2371493056.2020
Area: Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region, Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this afternoon and this evening. A well organized snow squall originating from Lake Huron will move across the area late this afternoon into this evening. At this point, it seems very likely this band will impact the afternoon/evening commute in the Golden Horseshoe from Oshawa to Hamilton. This band may also impact the 401 corridor from Oshawa to Kingston late this afternoon as well. This band will be capable of producing quick accumulations of 2 to 5 cm in an hour along with sudden reductions to visibility in heavy snow. The timing of this snowfall may potentially lengthen afternoon commute times significantly. Travelers are advised to exercise caution and allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T01:57:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-28T09:58:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1916809930.2020

properties.Summary:

These conditions will improve gradually near midday. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow is forecast to develop over sections of Highway 93 beginning late this afternoon. Total snowfall amounts near and south of Saskatchewan River Crossing are expected to be between 10 to 20 cm, however locally higher amounts are possible. Visibility in blowing and drifting snow is also possible throughout the day on Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: widespread 10 to 15 cm although some localized areas could receive a bit more or less due to local effects. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Locations: Bonavista North, Bay of Exploits and the straits side of the Northern Peninsula. Time span: until later this afternoon except until this evening over the straits side of the Northern Peninsula. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strong easterly winds to produce poor visibility at times in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-29T04:59:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-28T17:20:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4129170996.2020
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Port Saunders and the Straits

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 50. Extreme cold conditions are expected to moderate slightly throughout the day today but will once again return Friday night, with wind chill values of -50 forecast. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm except 45 to 55 cm south of Hare Bay. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 km/h. Locations: Northern Peninsula East. Time span: until late Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will persist through Saturday with the highest amounts and heaviest snowfall rates expected south of Hare Bay. The snow will combine with strong northeasterly winds to give poor visibility in blowing snow, especially today. Winds will diminish tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls into Saturday. Some well organized snow squalls east of Northern Lake Huron will move south and into the area this afternoon. These snow squalls will become more northwest this evening as winds shift to more northwesterly. Strong westerly winds today and northwesterly winds tonight combining with heavy snow in the snow squalls will produce blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. Local whiteout conditions may occur. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls possible this evening through Saturday. Conditions will remain favourable for snow squalls to develop off of Lake Huron into Saturday. Travel may become hazardous, and motorists are advised to consider changing their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-29T07:08:51-00:00
